<@U047GTU64> "Arguments" and "convicing" is not the way for two people to arrive at the same conclusion....

There is reasoning why the other person wants to do things one way and there is reasoning why you want to do it another. You both need to make clear and understand each other's reasoning, have empathy for the other person's point of view, arrive at an agreement on what the goal is you're both trying to achieve and then make a decision based on the fact and what serves the purpose you're trying to achieve.

Trying to "convince" someone of something is not how you align people in the same direction.

The key word above is "empathy". Have empathy for the other person, their point of view and their reasoning, and then show them where your reasoning is coming from.

<@U047GTU64> another thing I've found useful in helping organisations make decisions is agreeing to "guiding principles" that if any design idea interferes with there has to be proper justification/conversation. Very few people would disagree in the abstract that "Don't add to the stack unless you need to" is a good idea; it's only in concrete ideas that people become attached and religious. Having these principles helps the _offender_ to see the issue in a less "us then them/him/her" way and more of principles. Doesn't solve the problem but it does help to bring back to a more rational discussion.

Maybe I am a bit late into that discussion, as I love ES a lot and I am comfortable with it a lot as well, I’d say you both have to draft all pros and cons, sometimes, its not just enough saying, “its simple use case, so lets use MySQL”.

Depending on project and company possibilities, it can be more beneficial to add +1 technology, if it helps to lear, or, it will drastically increase productivity, because this person is much more capable in it.

BUT, before introducing it, you have to draft *everything* that is required, to make it work in production, starting from configuration, logging, fail-over, who will do upgrades, and in the end, count costs.
If you are both working for a company, one good thing that helps to resonate, is counting, how much things cost in the long run, eg. 1 year period

we, as a developers, sometimes, or even in more times, forget, that everything costs money, and when you are “business-minded” you have to think, how much your decision will produce “money-loss” and  how much “waste” will be after wards as well

I combat this type of thing with asking lots of questions. Force them to justify their opinion. Find all the edge cases. Find all the unknowns and the costs they hadn't considered. Investigate upgrade path later - if you go the other way are you blocking this permanently. Sometimes they realise for themselves that your way is better or more pragmatic. Other times they point out a shortcoming of your own assumptions and you have to eat crow.
